I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  Tajikistan  requested  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical 
assistance (TA) to prepare the rural development project to increase the productivity of farms 
and nonfarm enterprises within an environmentally sustainable management framework. The 
TA is included in ADB’s country assistance strategy and program for 2005. A fact-finding 
mission visited Tajikistan on 15–23 November 2004 to formulate the TA with the Government. 
The TA1 framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Tajikistan has continued its path of economic growth and macroeconomic stability, with 
average annual growth of 9.5% since 2000, and 10.6% in 2004. As a result of this growth, policy 
reforms, and favorable economic environment, poverty is estimated to have declined from 82% 
in 1999 to 64% in 2003, based on $2.15 per day poverty line. 
   
3.  Tajikistan is an agricultural economy. The sector has consistently grown at an average 
annual rate generally equal to or exceeding national economic growth. It accounts for 20% of 
the gross domestic product (GDP), employs about 52% of the labor force, and accounts for 
about 11% of export revenues (2003).  
 
4.  About 70% of the population lives in rural areas and relies mainly on agriculture for its 
livelihood. Poverty has declined mainly in the cotton-growing areas and has fallen only slightly in 
other rural areas. It remains widespread and inequality is worsening. The average per capita 
income is about $170 per year and the average household spends up to 90% of its income on 
food. Overseas jobs continue to be an important means of livelihood for many households.  
 
5.  The  crop  and  livestock  subsectors  continue  to  experience  substantial  adjustments. 
Cotton, wheat, potato, and vegetable production have increased by over 50% since 1999, while 
fruits have increased marginally by 14%, and grapes have declined. While cotton, grain, and 
potato yields have increased by over 50%, with vegetables by about 46%, average yields are 
still low and do not compare favorably with world averages. The low yields are attributed to: (i) 
deteriorating  soil  conditions;  (ii)  limited  availability  of  quality  agricultural  inputs;  (iii)  lack  of 
finance for investment and working capital; and (iv) lack of private sector involvement. Livestock 
has performed less well, with production increasing about 18% since 1999. Only dairy cattle and 
goats have exceeded 1991 production levels. 
 
6.  Subsistence  farming  has  increased  in  importance  as  the  key  source  of  food  and 
potential livelihood for many farmers, particularly in non-cotton-growing areas.  Small-scale 
private  farms  produce  much  of  the  food  supply.  Development  of  cereals,  potatoes,  other 
vegetables, and fruits has become increasingly important as a source of income for the poor. 
However, the food supply is inadequate: wheat production (730,000 tons) falls short of the 1.0 
million to 1.3 million tons needed annually; food prices are increasing (wheat flour by 67%, rice 
by 70%, and bread by 103% since 2001); and average per capita food intake has decreased 
from 2,615 kcal (1985) to 1,528 kcal (2003). Most households have a monthly income per capita 
below the cost of the minimal monthly food basket of TJS32 per capita. Hence, long-term food 
security  is  not  guaranteed.  Nevertheless,  households  are  adapting  to  the  changing 
circumstances  and  there  is  increasing  evidence  of  an  entrepreneurial  spirit  among  some 
households, farmers, and rural businesses.

7.  While agriculture is contributing to the economy, it is underperforming and therefore is 
not significantly reducing rural poverty. The main factors inhibiting more effective agriculture 
growth and development of rural areas include the following: (i) land is in various stages of 
privatization, with inadequate allocation and registration of rights, and people are now free to 
choose how land is used; (ii) farm productivity is generally low and unprofitable; (iii)  irrigation 
systems continue to deteriorate; (iv) soil degradation (declining soil fertility, increasing salinity, 
waterlogging, etc.) is serious and increasing; (v) deforestation has accelerated; (vi) availability of 
and access to finance is limited; (vii) farm machinery is obsolete, inadequate for the changing 
management and size of farms, and rarely in working order; (viii) agricultural research and 
extension  and  statistical  information  services  have  shrunk  substantially,  are  generally 
ineffective, and do not address the needs of emerging private farms in a market-oriented 
economy;  (ix)  marketing,  both  domestic  and  export,  is  severely  constrained  by  numerous 
informal trade barriers, generally weak demand for food in a largely subsistence economy, and 
poorly understood functions of organizations and personnel that manage market structures; 
(x) the vocational education system does not offer the formal and informal training needed by 
farmers and small businesses, many of whom have limited business experience; (xi) livestock is 
predominantly raised by households, mainly for subsistence, and is constrained by lack of 
markets  and  land  for  fodder  and  grazing;  (xii)  value-added  agroprocessing  is  limited; 
(xiii) coordination  among  public  sector  agencies  remains  limited,  as  does  their  capacity  to 
implement or enforce reforms and project activities; (xiv) the sector employs more than half of 
all women in rural areas, since a substantial proportion of the men migrate to Russia to work, 
but they are underrepresented in decision making, access to land, and training programs; (xv) a 
new system of services, based on private ownership and market principles, is emerging slowly, 
but new institutions are slow to develop in the absence of an enabling business environment, 
finance, farm profitability, and demand for inputs and services; and (xvi) the Government is 
increasingly devolving functions and responsibilities to local government and communities (e.g., 
irrigation rehabilitation), but not all have the resources and skills for decentralization to be 
effective. 
 
8.  Development assistance is generally increasing in agriculture and rural development, 
particularly  from  international  donors  and  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs).  ADB’s 
assistance to agriculture and rural development has been diverse, largely in the cotton sector, 
drainage  and  irrigation  rehabilitation,  rural  finance,  and  emergency  assistance  and  related 
institutional developments. These activities have usually been in many locations. 
 
9.  The number of agencies and scope of activities have expanded in recent years. The 
main agencies include the World Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, the United Nations 
Development Programme (UNDP) , the European Union, the Aga Khan Foundation, the Food 
and  Agriculture  Organization  (FAO)  of  the  United  Nations,  as  well  as  bilateral  agencies, 
including the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), the Government of 
Germany, the Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC), the United Kingdom 
Department for International Development (DFID), and NGOs. NGOs are moving away from 
humanitarian to development assistance in agriculture, microcredit, social services, and other 
related areas in rural development. The combined efforts of these agencies are helping the 
Government address the challenges above. However, to increase its effectiveness and impact, 
particularly in reducing poverty, development assistance needs to be more focused and better 
coordinated and to address priority issues and constraints. 
 
10.  A  more  holistic  and  coordinated  approach  is  proposed  to  address  problems  and 
constraints,  enhance  opportunities,  and  integrate  agriculture  more  effectively  into  the  rural

3
economy  through  a  coherent  rural  development  framework  or  strategy.2  This  will  involve 
identifying  priority  development  opportunities  for,  issues  related  to,  and  constraints  on  the 
development  of  agriculture  and  its  integration  into  rural  development.  This  will  entail  an 
incremental and sequential approach with realistic expectations of achievements. Increased 
coordination and cooperation among the development community and government agencies at 
all levels through adherence to the strategy will be important. 
 
11.  The TA proposes to pilot an integrated area-based approach comprising a number of 
contiguous raions (districts). This approach will initially develop a clear, realistic, and prioritized 
strategy  that  will  increase  the  productivity  of  farms  and  nonfarm  enterprises  within  an 
environmentally sustainable management framework, and increase the scope and depth of 
economic opportunities for farm and nonfarm rural residents. This approach, with the support of 
the Government and the donor community active in the area, will improve the coordination of 
development activities, efficient use of resources, and effective implementation and monitoring 
of development activities; generate economies of scale for marketing and processing activities; 
more effectively stimulate and encourage private sector development through farmers’ groups, 
cooperatives, and private companies; and provide a more dynamic environment for piloting and 
implementing policy, legislation and regulations, and institutional mechanisms.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The TA will help the Government design an investment project to provide an integrated 
approach to agriculture and rural development. 
 
13.  The TA will have two phases. The key output in phase I (3 months) will be a broad 
strategic plan to develop the selected area and identify investment activities to be funded by 
ADB. The strategy will cover policy, legal, institutional, and investment aspects. Phase II (5 
months) will produce a detailed feasibility study for the project, and institutional and monitoring 
and evaluation mechanisms to implement the strategic plan and project activities.  
 
14.  The geographical location for the project will be agreed on at the beginning of the TA, 
based on selection criteria to be agreed on with the Government. These criteria will include 
contiguous raions, non-cotton-growing areas, potential for crop diversification, reliable road 
access, high population density, poverty incidence, interest and capacity of local governments, 
and potential agreement among NGOs and donor partners to participate.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will be implemented through a participatory approach from the national to local 
government level and include the private sector (agricultural and nonagricultural business), 
donors,  NGOs,  civil  society,  and  farmers.  The  participatory  approach  will  be  implemented 
through the TA steering committee, raion-level working groups, stakeholder workshops, focus 
group interviews, and the social analysis survey in the selected area. 
 
16.  The activities in phase I will be: (i) an analysis of the growth and development of the 
selected area; (ii) an assessment of the key issues, constraints, opportunities, and priorities for

agriculture  and  rural  development;  (iii)  a  review  and  mapping  of  existing  and  planned 
government,  donor  partner,  and  NGO-supported  activities  against  the  constraints  and 
opportunities; (iv) an assessment of private sector activity in on- and off-farm enterprises and of 
potential  for  development;  (v)  an  institutional  analysis  of  the  capacity  of  local  government 
agencies; (vi) preparation of, and agreement between governments (national and local) and 
donor and NGO partners and communities to, the strategic plan; and (vii) identification of the 
broad investment activities to be funded by ADB. Phase II will prepare a detailed feasibility 
study  that  will  include  (i)  key  investment  activities;  (ii)  institutional  development  activities; 
(iii) clearly identified links to existing or planned investment activities of the government, donor 
partners, NGOs, and the private sector; and (iv) institutional, and monitoring and evaluation 
mechanisms to implement the broader strategic plan and project activities. Phase II will also 
present plans for (i) strengthening community involvement in design and implementation and 
links to local government, (ii) mainstreaming gender aspects during project implementation, and 
(iii) developing capacity to enhance community participation. 
 
17.  The project impact is increased scope and depth of economic opportunities for farm and 
nonfarm  rural  residents.  The  outcome  is  increased  productivity  of  farms  and  nonfarm 
enterprises  within  an  environmentally  sustainable  management  framework.  The  potential 
outputs could include rural infrastructure, agricultural support services from input supply to 
marketing, private sector support for agribusiness development and agroprocessing, diversified 
livelihood development activities, sustainable land management, institutional development, and 
support to microfinance. The project will complement other ongoing and proposed agriculture 
and  rural  development  activities.  Consideration  will  be  given  to  a  grant-financed  TA  to 
strengthen local government agencies in rural development.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,032,000 equivalent, comprising $644,000 in 
foreign exchange cost and $388,000 equivalent in local currency cost. The TA will be financed 
by ADB’s TA funding program in the amount of $700,000 and the remaining $150,000 on a 
grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund and administered by ADB. ADB will 
finance  $700,000  equivalent  consisting  of  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $206,000 
equivalent in local currency cost. The Government will provide $182,000 equivalent as office 
accommodation, counterpart staff, and transport, data collection, and logistics support. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan is in Appendix 2. The project is expected to obtain 
funding of up to $17.12 million equivalent over 6 years, comprising $8.77 million in loan funds 
and $8.35 million in grant funds. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) will be the Executing Agency (EA), and will appoint a 
senior official as TA director to coordinate, guide, and supervise the consultants. A project 
working group will be chaired by MOA, with representatives from the Ministry of Finance, 
Ministry of Economy and Trade, State Committee for Nature Protection and Forestry, State 
Committee for Land Management, Tajik Academy of Agricultural Sciences and other national 
agencies, the oblast (region) and raion governments, and donor partners and NGOs.   
 
20.  The TA will be undertaken over 8 months in two phases and is expected to begin in 
August 2005 and be completed in March 2006. About 76 person-months of consulting services 
(22 international and 54 domestic) will be required. The international experts will include a team

5
leader–economist–planner,  institutional  development  specialist,  agriculture  economist, 
environmentalist,  sociologist,  and  others  as  needed.  The  domestic  experts  will  include  an 
economist–deputy  team  leader,  institutional  specialist,  rural  engineer,  rural  sociologist, 
agribusiness specialist, environmental specialist (sustainable land management), agriculture–
livestock specialist, and others as needed. The services of a firm will be engaged in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB 
for engaging domestic consultants. A simplified technical proposal using the quality- and cost-
based selection procedure will be adopted for recruiting the consulting firm. The consultants will 
procure computer and other approved equipment in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
Procurement. The equipment will be transferred to MOA at the end of the TA. An initial poverty 
and social impact assessment of the project is in Appendix 4. 
 
21.  Several participatory workshops will be held to strengthen the participatory approach. 
Workshops will be held at the start of phase I to review the agriculture and rural development 
situation, and at the end of phase I to discuss and agree on the strategic plan and the potential 
project. Only when agreement is reached will phase II commence. Workshops at the local 
government and community levels, and including donor partners, NGOs, and the private sector, 
will continue to formulate the project design and ensure ownership of and agreement to the 
detailed design and implementation arrangements. 
 
22.  Inception, phase-I, interim, draft final, and final reports will be prepared. Tripartite review 
meetings will discuss their findings and recommendations. All reports will be in English and 
Russian, and, where appropriate, summarized in Tajik. 
 
23.  The Government will provide: (i) administrative assistance to the consultants to help 
them fulfill their terms of reference; (ii) all relevant documents and information available to 
agencies within the government; (iii) adequate office space with appropriate furniture; (iv) local 
communications facilities and direct access to international communications facilities (the cost of 
international communications will be borne by the consultants); and (v) counterpart staff to work 
with the consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved: (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $150,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund, and (ii) ADB providing 
the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis, to the Government of 
Tajikistan for preparing the Rural Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will have two phases. In phase I, the state of agriculture 
development in the selected raions (districts) will be comprehensively reviewed to identify major 
issues  related  to,  constraints  on,  and  opportunities  for  further  agriculture  growth  and 
development.  Institutional  and  financial  analyses  of  the  region's  administration  and,  where 
necessary,  of  districts,  villages,  farmers’  organizations,  and  other  relevant  agencies  will 
determine their capacity and strategic needs for assistance. Ongoing and planned development 
activities by the Government, private sector, and funding agencies will be reviewed. A rural 
development framework or strategy will be prepared for the selected area and agreed on with 
the Government, donor partners, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), the private sector, and 
communities. Alternative approaches to addressing issues, constraints, and opportunities will be 
assessed and key areas for Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance identified. In phase II, 
the project will be designed, taking account of the findings in phase I; the reassessment of the 
alternative approaches; and policy, technical, economic, financial, social, environmental, and 
institutional aspects.  
 
A.  Phase 1: Review of the Selected Area 
 
2.  The  review  of  the  districts  can  be  based  largely  on  existing  reports  and  project 
documents and should include one or more workshops with the Government, private sector, civil 
society, and donor partners. 
 
3.  The analysis of the overall growth and development of the region and districts will cover 
 
(i)  the macroeconomic and sectoral context of the selected area, with attention to 
the  constraints  identified  in  para.  7  of  the  TA  paper,  and  drawing  on  the 
economic and sector work of ADB and other agencies; 
(ii)  growth and development of each area, based on national and regional statistics; 
(iii)  the  progress  of  agricultural  reforms,  and  identify  any  major  constraints  on 
implementation, and additional reforms to facilitate the transition to a market-
based agriculture sector; 
(iv)  the  achievements  of  regional  development  efforts  by  local  governments,  the 
private sector, and funding agencies;  
(v)  the  socioeconomic  situation,  and  identify  major  economic  and  social  issues 
affecting the rural population, with attention to women and vulnerable groups, 
and the effects of farm restructuring, reduction of social services, and access to 
resources (including land) and infrastructure; and 
(vi)  an assessment of rural–urban linkages. 
 
4.  The assessment of development in agriculture will address 
 
(i)  the ownership and structure of farms in the region and factors influencing the 
success of private farming, and identify constraints that inhibit the improvement 
of farm productivity and profitability, by farm type, farm size, ownership, land, 
labor and capital availability, output, productivity, and net income, disaggregated 
by farm enterprise and, where applicable, by gender; 
(ii)  the market potential for the area, competitiveness of the products, potential for 
increased competitiveness, and constraints on achieving this competitiveness, 
including a comparative advantage analysis of the project area;

10  Appendix 3 
(iii)  availability  of,  and  farmers'  access  to,  input  supplies,  technology,  finance, 
markets  and  marketing  facilities  and  channels,  extension  and  research,  and 
transport  and  distribution  networks,  with  major  constraints  and  opportunities 
identified; and 
(iv)  the links between agriculture and the broader rural economy. 
 
5.  The assessment of infrastructure will focus on 
 
(i)  the  condition  of  off-  and  on-farm  drainage  and  irrigation  infrastructure,  and 
responsibilities for and financing of operation and maintenance; and 
(ii)  the condition of rural roads and the main constraints on effective repair and 
maintenance. 
 
6.  The institutional aspects to be addressed include 
 
(i)  the  roles,  responsibilities,  and  capacity  of  institutions  supporting  agriculture, 
particularly agriculture administration, and of agencies responsible for delivering 
agriculture  support  services;  strengths,  weaknesses,  and  needs  of,  and 
opportunities for, institutional strengthening will be identified; 
(ii)  number, strength, and effectiveness of cooperatives and other agriculture-based 
organizations, and arrangements for supporting their development; 
(iii)  private  sector  involvement  in  agriculture,  particularly  in  rural  finance,  input 
supply,  machine  leasing,  output  storage,  agroprocessing,  and  marketing, 
including  the  role  of  cooperatives  and  farmers  associations;  constraints  on 
private sector investment will be identified; 
(iv)  the role, approach, and activities of NGOs and the private sector in the area; and 
(v)  formal and informal training of farmers; current support by the Government and 
aid-funded  institutions  and  activities  will  be  assessed,  and  opportunities  for 
expanding  formal  and  informal  training  in  a  cost-effective  and  sustainable 
manner identified. 
 
7.  An assessment of partner agencies for development will involve 
 
(i)  analyzing ongoing and proposed project activities in the area, including support 
for land and property distribution, farm restructuring, commercial seed industry, 
livestock  industry  development,  contract  farming  services,  farmer  advisory 
services or group formation, market information, farm surveys, major irrigation 
system  rehabilitation  and  on-farm  drainage  and  irrigation,  rural  finance,  and 
forestry; and 
(ii)  preparing a database of programs to highlight the objectives, scope, area focus, 
financing, special features, and possible links to the project. 
 
8.  Based on the preceding analysis, the consultant will 
 
(i)  prepare a development framework or strategy to develop the area and facilitate 
coordination of development activities; 
(ii)  conduct a workshop to discuss and agree on the strategy among stakeholders; 
and 
(iii)  obtain agreement from the Government before proceeding to phase II.

10.  The feasibility design of the project will follow from the development strategy and the 
identification, review, and preliminary assessments of alternative design features in phase I. The 
project will take 6 years to establish productive and profitable farms and sustainable regional 
support services, and public and private sector investments. 
 
11.  Subject  to  confirmation  in  phase  I  of  the  TA,  the  components  to  be  prepared  for 
feasibility design in phase II can include: (i) development of farms as commercial enterprises; (ii) 
sustainable land management activities, including policy, planning, budgeting, and investment; 
(iii) agribusiness services, including market surveys, marketing, farm technology, input supply, 
machinery  services  and  repair,  and  private  agribusiness  advisory  services;  (iv)  market 
infrastructure, on-farm irrigation and drainage, farm-to-market roads, and drinking water supply; 
(v)  institutional  development  of  regional  and  district  administrations  and  departments  of 
agriculture; village, water user organizations, and farmers’ associations; identification of human 
resource and training needs and related development of regional agricultural training institutions 
such as technical and vocational schools; and (vi) policy and legal measures to encourage a 
market-based agriculture system.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Republic of Tajikistan: 
 
Tajikistan is agricultural, with about 70% of the population in rural areas and relying mainly on agriculture for its 
livelihood. In 2003, 70% of the rural population was below the poverty line, a decline from 81% in 1999. The decline 
was more prevalent in the main cotton-growing areas and fell only slightly in other rural areas. However, the Gini 
coefficient indicates a worsening of inequality, increasing from 0.33 in 1999 to 0.36 in 2003. Poverty remains 
widespread. The average per capita income is about $170 per year, and the average household spends up to 90% of 
its income on food. Overseas jobs continue to be an important means of livelihood for many households. An estimated 
1 million people (15% of the population) live in households whose main source of income is derived from a family 
member working abroad.3 Remittances increased from $65 million in 2002 to $202 million in 2003. 
 
Subsistence farming has increased in importance as the key source of food and potential livelihood for many farmers, 
particularly in non-cotton-growing areas.  Small-scale private farms produce much of Tajikistan’s food. Growing 
cereals, potatoes, and other vegetables, and fruits has become increasingly important as a source of income for the 
poor. The food supply is inadequate. Wheat, the staple crop, is grown on 35% of the irrigated area, but the total 
production of about 730,000 tons falls short of the 1.0 million to 1.3 million tons needed annually. Food prices are 
increasing, with wheat flour rising by 67%, rice by 70%, and bread by 103% since 2001. Average per capita food 
intake has also decreased from 2,615 kilocalories (kcal) (1985) to 1,528 kcal (2003). Most households have a monthly 
income per capita below the cost of the minimal monthly food basket of TJS32 per capita. Hence, long-term food 
security is not guaranteed.  
 
Poverty in Tajikistan is non-income-based, characterized by a worsening human development situation caused by the 
lack of essential services, and increasing economic and social disparities that particularly affect women.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                         Proposed Poverty Classification: Targeted intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
  The technical assistance (TA) will require a poverty analysis that is disaggregated by raion (district) and by gender. 
The geographical area is still to be selected by the Government and agreed to by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). This will be done when the TA begins. It will look at the incidence of poverty using existing data sources and 
a social survey of potential beneficiaries. Income and non-income poverty indexes  will be determined. The analysis 
will be carried out following the Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis and Handbook for Integrating Poverty 
Impact on Economic Analysis of Projects. Particular attention is to be given to profiling the beneficiaries, including 
gender-disaggregated demographic, economic, and social data where possible, plus the incidence of poverty, 
vulnerable groups, and any adverse impacts anticipated from the project.
